JavaScript can we maybe take like a step back and talk a little bit about like
the overall problem of fonts loading on the web for people who are not familiar with that sure yeah so so when you add a
add a web font to your code um basically there's a couple of different things that happen when the
font loads the biggest problem primarily is that browsers will hide any text
using that font for up to 3 seconds while the font loads and then if the font hasn't loaded within 3 seconds it
will show your fallback text it will render sort of your system font fallback in your font family stack um and then it
will rerender after the font has loaded successfully so you kind of have like this up to two different stages of
rendering that can happen uh you have invisible text then you could have fallback text then you get your web font
and so that's really problematic when it comes to web fonts because not not just the perceived performance of you want
your text to render like you want your text to be visible and readable as soon as like the page renders on first render
you want readable text but when you have multiple fonts interacting you get some
weird race conditions that can happen so like when you have uh a web font for a
title and then in a different web font for like your italics using of that same font family you can get some weird like
partially visible text like each each uh web font has its own loading cycle so
and they all can finish at different different times so it's really kind of a
weird resource that isn't really treated in any other way like any other resource on the web it's kind of has its own
unique problems yeah I really like your um I think you've given you've showed this example in like multiple talks
you've given where there's like an example of a news site that's like Mitt Romney is running for president because
the knot like didn't load yeah they like italicized a not cuz he was not running

fonts uh on your page you can find out when those render uh and then render
